entry.title: Ravenswood standing stone (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 4,000-year-old Ravenswood standing stone (pictured) now lies in a cul-de-sac in a 1970s Scottish housing estate?

entry.title: Dov Noy (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Dov Noy founded the Israel Folktale Archives, which have collected around 25,000 Jewish folk tales?

entry.title: Choco Togo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Choco Togo produces heat-resistant chocolate bars that can withstand temperatures of up to 35 °C (95 °F)?

entry.title: Sun Zhiyang (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that one newspaper expected mayor Sun Zhiyang to help turn Guangzhou into a "smart car city"?

entry.title: an Academy Award–shortlisted documentary (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Jennifer Brea directed an Academy Award–shortlisted documentary while bedbound from ME/CFS?

entry.title: DI MA-1 Mk. III (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the DI MA-1 Mk. III rifle was made in Myanmar as a reverse-engineered copy of the Chinese QBZ-97?

entry.title: sport in Vatican City (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that sport in Vatican City has included cricket, calcio fiorentino, and taekwondo?

entry.title: a scrapped song (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a scrapped song from SZA's second album was supposed to be on her next one, but when the song was leaked she had to scrap it again?

entry.title: Mary Owens (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Abraham Lincoln felt obliged to propose to Mary Owens – a woman he did not want to marry – but was rejected several times?
